title: An Expert Ensemble for Detecting Anomalous Scenes, Interactions, and Behaviors in Autonomous Driving
author: Tianchen Ji (University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign), Neeloy Chakraborty (University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign), Andre Schreiber, Katherine Driggs-Campbell, ...
relevance_why: The ensemble approach for anomaly detection in autonomous driving scenarios could inspire similar methodologies in audio event detection and enhance robustness in detecting sound anomalies in complex environments.
background: Detecting unusual events in real-time from driving video feeds to ensure the safety of autonomous vehicles in complex driving environments.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework employing three distinct expert modules to effectively detect various anomaly types in autonomous driving, achieving improved detection performance on large-scale datasets.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focused on either frame-level or object-centric anomaly detection but struggled in capturing the full spectrum of anomalies due to the complexity of driving scenarios.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work incorporates a multi-expert framework that combines scene, interaction, and behavior analysis, leading to a more comprehensive and accurate detection capability.

key_innovation: The integration of multiple specialized experts into a Kalman filter-based ensemble allows for heightened detection of both subtle and obvious anomalies in real-time driving data.
real_world_impact: The proposed method could significantly enhance the safety and reliability of autonomous vehicles by enabling them to recognize and respond to unexpected situations more effectively.
limitations: The paper does not mention specific limitations, but the reliance on video data may pose challenges in varied environmental conditions affecting performance.

new_terms.Kalman filter: **Kalman filter** is an algorithm that uses a series of measurements observed over time to estimate unknown variables, thereby providing predictions that are statistically optimal.
